abstract.text: Direct (prompt) photon production is a field of very high interest in hadron colliders.
It provides probes to search for new phenomena and to test QCD predictions.

In this article, two recent cross-section results for direct photon production using the full CDF Run II data set are presented: diphoton production and photon production in association with a heavy quark.

body_text.text: Introduction
Direct photon (γ) production in hadron colliders provides a clean probe to test quantum chromodynamics (QCD) predictions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A better understanding of such processes can improve the background modeling in the searches for new physics with photon final state.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this article, two recent cross-section results for direct photon production in pp collisions at √ s = 1.96 TeV are presented: diphoton production [1] and photon production in association with a heavy quark Q (b or c) [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Both results use the full data set collected by the CDF II detector.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The CDF II detector [3] has a cylindrical geometry with approximate forward-backward and azimuthal symmetry.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It contains a tracking system consisting of silicon microstrip detectors and a cylindrical open-cell drift chamber immersed in a 1.4 T magnetic field parallel to the beam axis.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The silicon subsystem is used for reconstructing charged-particle trajectories (tracks) and heavyflavor-decay vertices displaced from the primary interaction point.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Electromagnetic (EM) and hadronic calorimeters surrounding the tracking system with pointing-tower geometry are used to measure photon energies.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: At a depth approximately corresponding to the maximum development of the EM shower, the EM calorimeters contain finegrained detectors (central electromagnetic strip chambers) that measure the shower profile.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Drift chambers and scintillators located outside the calorimeters identify muons.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

Precise measurements of the production cross sections for diphotons are important for the searches for new phenomena, such as extra spatial dimensions, and for improvements in the precision of the measurements of the production cross section and the decay branching ratio of the Higgs boson into a photon pair.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: Diphoton production is a e-mail: tjyang@fnal.gov also used to test QCD both in the perturbative scheme (pQCD) and in nonperturbative schemes, such as softgluon resummation methods and photons from quark fragmentation.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: This article presents the final diphoton measurements from CDF using the full data set collected in 2001-2011 corresponding to a total integrated luminosity of 9.5 fb −1 .
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: Inclusive diphoton events are selected online by requiring two isolated electromagnetic clusters with E T > 12 GeV each or two electromagnetic clusters with E T > 18 GeV and no isolation requirement.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: In the offline analysis additional requirements are imposed to identify a sample rich in prompt photons.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The pseudorapidity of each photon in the event is restricted to the region |η| < 1.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The photon transverse energy is required to exceed 17 GeV for the first photon and 15 GeV for the second photon.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The transverse energy measured by the calorimeter in an isolation cone with a radius in η − φ space of 0.4 around each photon is required not to exceed 2 GeV.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The background from events where one or both reconstructed photons are misidentified jets is subtracted with a 4 × 4 matrix technique using the track isolation as the discriminant between the signal and background [4].
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The differential cross section for diphoton production is obtained from the histogram of the estimated signal yield as a function of each relevant kinematic variable.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The average cross section in a bin is determined by dividing the yield by the product of the trigger efficiency, the selection efficiency and acceptance, the integrated luminosity, and the bin size.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The experimental results are compared with six theoretical calculations:
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: (i) the fixed NLO predictions of the  program, including nonperturbative parton fragmentation into photons at NLO,
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: (ii) the predictions of the  program where the cross section is accurate to NLO, but also has an analytical initial-state soft-gluon resummation,
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: (iii) the predictions of the  partonshower program including photons radiated from initialand final-state quarks,
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: (iv) the fixed NLO predictions of the  program, including nonperturbative parton frag- mentation into photons at LO,
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: (v) the fixed next-to-nextto-leading order (NNLO) predictions of a recent calculation, and
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: (vi) the predictions of the  program, based on a matrix element calculation merged with the parton shower model.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The measured cross section for diphoton production integrated over the acceptance is 12.3 ± 0.2 stat ± 3.5 syst pb.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The predictions for the integrated cross section are 10.6 ± 0.6 pb from , 11.3 ± 2.4 pb from , 9.2 pb from , 12.4 ± 4.4 pb from , 11.5 ± 0.3 pb from , and 11.8 +1.7 −0.6 pb from the NNLO calculation.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The  scale uncertainty is large because it also accounts for parton shower.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The  uncertainty is unreported.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: All predictions are consistent with the measurement.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: Figure 1 shows the comparisons between the observed and predicted distributions in diphoton mass M, transverse momentum P T of the photon pair, and azimuthal separation ∆φ between the momenta of the two photons in the event.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: All predictions for the mass distribution show a reasonable agreement with the data for all calculations above the maximum at 30 GeV/c 2 except the  γγ calculation.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: All predictions underestimate the data rate around and below the maximum.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: In the P T spectrum, the , ,  and  predictions underestimate the data in the region between 30 and 60 GeV/c, where the contribution from quark fragmentation is important.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: Both NNLO and  predictions describe the data fairly well in this region.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: For P T < 20 GeV/c, where soft-gluon radiation becomes important, the ,  and  predictions provide a good description of the data because of the resummation of multiple soft-gluon emission amplitudes through either analytical calculation or parton showering.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The fixed-order predictions diverge in the limit of vanishing P T .
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The ,  and  predictions show a good agreement with the data at larger ∆φ, where the diphoton system acquires substantial transverse momentum due to multiple soft-gluon emission.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: The NNLO calculation is the only prediction consistent with the data in the low ∆φ tail, which contains photon pairs with very low mass and relatively high P T .
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Diphoton Production

body_text.text: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

The cross section for direct photon production in association with a heavy quark in hadronic collisions provides valuable information on the probability distributions of partons inside the initial-state hadrons.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: At photon transverse energy E γ T smaller than 100 GeV, such events are produced predominantly by the Compton scattering process, while at higher energies the dominant process is quark-antiquark annihilation with gluon (g) splitting to heavy quarks.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: It is conventional to assume that the charm (c) and bottom
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: (b) quarks in the proton arise only from gluon splitting.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: However, there are other models that allow the existence of intrinsic heavy quarks in the proton.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: A cross-section measurement of γ + Q + X (X can be any final-state particle) production provides information  on the heavy-quark and gluon parton distribution functions (PDFs) and on the rate of final-state gluon splitting to heavy quarks.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: This article presents the final CDF measurements of the cross sections for photon with heavy-flavor jets, using the full data set from 9.1 fb −1 of integrated luminosity, exploring E γ T up to 300 GeV.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The photo-plus-heavy-jet events are selected online by requiring at least one energy cluster consistent with a photon in the final state.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The offline event selection required each event to have at least one photon candidate that has pseudorapidity in the fiducial region of the central calorimeter (|η| < 1).
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Photon candidates are required to have E γ T > 30 GeV.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: An artifical neural network (ANN) is constructed to reduce background.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: At least one jet must be present in each event.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Jets are reconstructed using the JETCLU algorithm with a cone radius 0.4.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: We select jets that have E T > 20 GeV and |η| < 1.5.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: At least one jet is required to be classified as a heavy-flavor jet using a secondary-vertex tagger.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The selected jet is required to be reconstructed in a volume outside a cone with a radius in η − φ space of 0.4 surrounding the photon candidate.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: There are two main background sources: jets misidentified as photons (false photons) and light-flavor jets mimicking heavy-flavor jets.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: To estimate the rate of false photons, the photon ANN distribution in data is fitted to a linear combination of templates for photons and jets, obtained from simulated samples.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: A fit is performed in each E γ T interval to get the prompt photon fractions (purities).
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: One example fit is shown in Figure 2.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Backgrounds to heavy-flavor jets arise from lightflavor jets where random combinations of tracks mimic a displaced vertex.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The fractions of b-and c-jets are determined by fitting the invariant mass (M SecVtx ) of the system of charged particles, assumed to be pions, originating at the secondary vertex, using the templates for b-, c-, and light-quark jets constructed with a simulated sample.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The contribution to the M SecVtx distribution from events with a false photon is modeled using dijet data.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Figure 3 shows  the result of the fit for E γ T between 40 and 50 GeV, as an example.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The differential cross section is obtained from the histogram of the estimated signal yield as a function of photon E T .
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The average cross section in a bin is determined by dividing the yield by the product of the trigger efficiency, the selection efficiency and acceptance, the integrated luminosity, and the bin size.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The experimental results are compared with four theoretical calculations:
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: (i) the fixed NLO calculations, including direct photon production subprocesses and subprocesses where the photon is emitted from parton fragmentation, both at O(αα 2 s ),
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: (ii) the k Tfactorization calculations, including O(αα 2 s ) off-shell amplitudes of gluon-gluon fusion and quark-(anti)quark interaction subprocesses, and the k T -dependent (i.e., unintegrated) parton distributions, where k T denotes the transverse momentum of the parton,
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: (iii) the  calculations, including all the tree-level matrix-element diagrams with one photon and up to three jets, with at least one b jet or c jet in the explored kinematic region,
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: (iv) the  calculations, including the 2 → 2 matrix-element subprocesses gb → γb and qq → γg with g → bb and g → cc splittings in the parton shower.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Previous studies [5] showed that the contribution of gluon splitting to heavy flavor has to be approximately doubled over expectations from the leading-order  generator to reproduce the data.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Hence, we also show predictions that include a double gluon-splitting rate to heavy flavors.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Figure 4 shows the comparisons between the observed and predicted distributions in photon E T .
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The NLO pQCD predictions agree with data at low E γ T but fail to describe data for E γ T > 70 GeV for the bottom-jet cross section.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The same trend is observed in the charm-jet cross section even though the experimental uncertainty is larger.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: For large E γ T , the dominant production process yielding a photon and a heavy quark involves a final-state gluon splitting into a heavy-flavor pair.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: This process is present only at leading order in the NLO calculation.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The  prediction allows up to three partons in the final state, through the inclusion of additional tree-level amplitudes.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The additional amplitudes also serve as a source of heavy-flavor pairs (through gluon splitting), which is important for the high E γ
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: T range.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The k T -factorization and  predictions are in reasonable agreement with the measured cross sections.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: The  predictions disagree with the data both in rate and in shape.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Scaling the  prediction and doubling the rate for g → bb or g → cc leads to an improved agreement with the data.
body_text.section: Cross Section for Direct Photon Production in Association with a Heavy Quark

body_text.text: Conclusions
In conclusion, we measure the differential cross sections for diphoton production and for inclusive production of a photon in association with a heavy flavor quark.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The observed cross sections are compared with a wide variety of theoretical predictions.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The results are important for high precision measurements of the recently discovered Higgs bosonlike particle and searches for new phenomena in diphoton final states and in final states involving the production of photons in association with heavy-flavor quarks.
body_text.section: Conclusions
